conclusion: Block C moves rightward with speed v₀ on the skateboard top, which is at rest relative to ground.
Kinetic friction μmg acts over the distance s₀, so C’s speed just before it reaches B is v₁ = √(v₀² – 2μgs₀).
C must satisfy v₀² > 2μgs₀ for contact actually to occur.
Block B is at rest immediately before the collision.
Total mechanical energy (translational) of the two small blocks is therefore ½ m v₁².
The impact is perfectly inelastic, so C and B stick together and move as one body of mass 2m with speed v₂ right after impact.
Linear‐momentum conservation gives m v₁ = (2m) v₂ ⇒ v₂ = v₁ ⁄ 2.
Kinetic energy just before impact: E_before = ½ m v₁².
Kinetic energy just after impact: E_after = ¼ m v₁².
Loss ΔE = E_before – E_after = ¼ m v₁².
Using v₁ = √(v₀² – 2μgs₀), ΔE = ¼ m ( v₀² – 2μgs₀ ).
The mechanical energy dissipated in the collision is ΔE = ¼ m ( v₀² – 2μgs₀ ).
